newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends down on LME loss.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends down on LME loss.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down in dull trading on Friday due to overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange with most investors withdrawing their funds, traders said.
The most active January 1997 contract ended at 20,040 yuan ($2,414) per tonne, losing 10 yuan. It opened unchanged at 20,050 yuan, hitting an intra-day high of 20,060 and a low of 19,960.
October fell 100 to 20,330 yuan, November 40 to 20,160, December 40 to 20,110, February 10 to 20,040 and March 70 to 20,070.
Combined volume fell to 9,160 tonnes form 22,240.
Copper opened mostly down and moved around 20,000 yuan for most of the session.
Traders said LME losses triggered some selling but short-covering on the unclear short-term market trend prevented prices from dropping further.
"LME losses was the major factor and most investors were not willing to build new positions ahead of the weekend," one trader said.
"The unclear short-term trend made later-maturing contracts find strong support at 20,000 yuan," he added.
Traders said poor domestic fundamentals made many investors move their money to other more active markets such as the stock market.
Recent further restriction of futures trading by China's top securities authorities also made some money flow out of the metals market, they said.
Aluminium ended down. October did not trade. November fell 80 to 13,820 yuan per tonne and December 120 to 13,730.
Combined volume rose to 870 tonnes from 220.
